LARGE GENERATOR INTERCONNECTION AGREEMENT
CO-TENANCY AGREEMENT
by and among
ROADRUNNER SOLAR LLC, ROADRUNNER BATTERY STORAGE LLC, And ROADRUNNER BESS SF LLC
TABLE OF CONTENTS Page ARTICLE I. DEFINITIONS 2 1.1 Certain Definitions 2 ARTICLE II. CO-TENANCY RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS 6 2.1 Declaration of Intention 6 2.2 Use of LGIA 6 2.3 Maximum Capacity 6 2.4 Curtailment 7 2.5 LGIA Expenses 7 2.6 Changes in Maximum Capacity 7 2.7 Liquidated Damages; Credits; Refunds 8 2.8 Joint and Several Liability 8 2.9 Projected Capacity 8 2.10 Indemnity 8 2.11 Taxes 9 2.12 Operation and Management 9 2.13 Events of Default 10 2.14 Remedies 11 2.15 Disconnection 11 2.16 Bankruptcy Provisions 11 2.17 Equitable Relief 11 2.18 Dispute Resolution 12 2.19 Effect of Force Majeure 12 2.20 Notice of Default 13 2.21 Performance under LGIA 13 2.22 Insurance 13 2.23 FERC Filing 13 ARTICLE III. MANAGER 13 3.1 Appointment of Manager; Manager Services 13 3.2 Communications 14 3.3 Indemnification of Manager 14 3.4 Books and Records; Reporting Requirements 14 3.5 Replacement of Manager 14 3.6 Management Fee 15 3.7 Discrimination 15 3.8 Performance 15 3.9 Termination of LGIA 16 ARTICLE IV. TRANSFERABILITY 16 4.1 Transfers 16 4.2 Right to Encumber 17 ARTICLE V. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 18 5.1 Notices 18 5.2 Governing Law 18 5.3 Entire Agreement 18 5.4 Interpretation 19 5.5 Waiver 19 5.6 Third Party Beneficiaries 19 5.7 Counterparts; Facsimile Signatures 19 5.8 Amendments; Term 19 5.9 Further Assurances 19 5.10 Severability 20 5.11 Successors and Assigns 20 5.10 WAIVER OF RIGHT TO PARTITION 20
LARGE GENERATOR INTERCONNECTION AGREEMENT CO-TENANCY AGREEMENT This LARGE GENERATOR INTERCONNECTION AGREEMENT CO-TENANCY AGREEMENT (this Agreement) is made and entered into as of December 20, 2024, by and among ROADRUNNER SOLAR LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (Roadrunner PV), ROADRUNNER BATTERY STORAGE LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (Roadrunner BESS) (each of Roadrunner PV and Roadrunner BESS may be referred to as a Co-Tenant and, collectively, as the Co-Tenants) and Roadrunner BESS SF LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (the Manager). Each Co-Tenant and the Manager may be referred to as a Party and, collectively, as the Parties. RECITALS A. Roadrunner PV is developing an approximately 235 MWac/290 MWdc rated solar photovoltaic (PV) generation project on real property located in Cochise County, Arizona that will include PV modules, inverters and associated collection and interconnection lines and related facilities and improvements (collectively, the Roadrunner PV Project). B. Roadrunner BESS is developing an approximately 235 MWac/940 MWh battery energy storage system (BESS) on real property located in Cochise County, Arizona that will include battery storage facilities and associated collection and interconnection lines, related facilities and improvements (the Roadrunner BESS Project) (each of the Roadrunner PV Project and the Roadrunner BESS Project may be referred to individually as a Project and, collectively, as the Projects). C. The Co-Tenants and Arizona Electric Power Cooperative, Inc., a non-profit corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of Arizona (Transmission Provider), entered into that certain Amended and Restated Standard Large Generator Interconnection Agreement, dated as of February 16, 2024 (as may be further amended, amended and restated, or otherwise modified from time to time, the LGIA), for the purpose of securing interconnection rights for the Projects. D. The LGIA is the successor agreement to the Large Generator Interconnection Agreement, dated August 4, 2023, by and between Roadrunner PV and Transmission Provider, which set forth rights and responsibilities for the interconnection of the Roadrunner PV Project. NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the foregoing and the agreements and covenants contained herein, and other good and valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which are hereby acknowledged, the Parties hereto agree as follows: AGREEMENT Article I. DEFINITIONS 1.1 Certain Definitions. Capitalized words and phrases used herein shall have the following meanings, or the meanings given in the Sections of this Agreement in which they are defined, unless the text expressly or by necessary implication requires otherwise. (a) Affiliate means, when used with respect to any Person, any other Person directly or indirectly controlling, controlled by, or under common control with such Person. For this definition, the terms controlling, controlled by or under common control mean the possession, directly or indirectly, of the power to direct or cause the direction of management or policies (whether through ownership of securities or any partnership or other ownership interest, by contract or otherwise) of a Person. (b) Agreement has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (c) Arbitration Rules has the meaning given forth in Section 2.18. (d) Bankruptcy means any case, action or proceeding under any bankruptcy, reorganization, insolvency or receivership law or any dissolution or liquidation proceeding commenced by or against a Person and, if such case, action or proceeding is not commenced by such Person, such case or proceeding shall be consented to or acquiesced in by such Person or shall result in an order for relief, or shall remain undismissed for ninety (90) days. (e) Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest means, with respect to each Co-Tenant, as of any date of determination, the percentage interest set forth on Exhibit A hereto, as such exhibit may be amended from time to time. (f) Co-Tenant has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (g) Construction Costs means the costs incurred in connection with the design, engineering and construction of the Interconnection Customers Interconnection Facilities, which shall be allocated in accordance with the Shared Facilities Agreement. (h) Effective Date means the date first written above. (i) Event of Default has the meaning given in Section 2.13. (j) FERC means the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission or any successor agency. (k) FERC Filing has the meaning given in Section 2.23. (l) Financing Party means, with respect to a Co-Tenant, any Person providing direct or indirect debt or equity financing, refinancing or extending credit (including any financing lease) to such Co-Tenant (or to such Co-Tenants Affiliate that is a Co-Tenant under the Shared Facilities Agreement) with respect to such Co-Tenant. For the purposes of this Agreement, with respect to a Co-Tenant, any counterparty to such Co-Tenant (or to such Co-Tenants Affiliate that is a Co-Tenant under the Shared Facilities Agreement) with respect to such Co-Tenant in a swap, option collar or cap involving, or settled by reference to, one (1) or more commodities (including power and transmission) or meteorological conditions (whether financial or physical), in each case, in connection with the purchase, installation or operation of the applicable solar photovoltaic panels or such Co-Tenants Project, shall be a Financing Party hereunder. (m) Force Majeure has the meaning given in the LGIA. (n) FPA has the meaning given in Section 2.12. (o) Governmental Approval means any permit, license, certificate, concession, approval, consent, ratification, permission, clearance, confirmation, exemption, waiver, franchise, certification, designation, rating, registration, variance, qualification, accreditation or authorization issued, granted, given or otherwise made available by or under the authority of any Governmental Authority or pursuant to any Law. (p) Governmental Authority means any court, tribunal, authority, agency, commission, official or other instrumentality, including regulatory authorities and bodies, of the United States or any state, county, city, school district, hospital district, or other political subdivision, any quasi-governmental regulatory authority, such as NERC, or NERCs regional reliability entities acting under delegated authority, as well as any arbitrator or any judicial or quasi-judicial tribunal of competent jurisdiction. (q) Indemnified Party has the meaning given in Section 2.10. (r) Indemnifying Party has the meaning given in Section 2.10. (s) Interconnection Capacity means the interconnection capacity of the Projects expressed in MW, as measured at the Point of Interconnection, provided for pursuant to the LGIA; as of the Effective Date, the Interconnection Capacity set forth in the LGIA is 235 MW. (t) Interconnection Customer has the meaning given in the LGIA. (u) Interconnection Customers Interconnection Facilities has the meaning given in the LGIA. (v) Interconnection Facilities has the meaning given in the LGIA. (w) [Reserved.] (x) Interest Rate means a rate per annum equal to the lesser of (a) a varying rate per annum equal to the sum of (i) the prime rate as defined and published in The Wall Street Journal, with adjustments in that varying rate to be made on the same date as any change in that rate is so published, plus (ii) two percent (2%) per annum and (b) the maximum rate permitted by Law. (y) Lessor means a Co-tenant under the Shared Facilities Agreement that leases its undivided interest under the Shared Facilities Agreement to a Co-Tenant under this Agreement. (z) Laws means all applicable laws, statutes, ordinances, rules, regulations, decrees, orders, permits, requirements, judgments, decisions and injunctions issued by any governmental authority, including laws relating to health, safety and the environment. (aa) LGIA has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (bb) LGIA Liabilities has the meaning given in Section 2.5(c). (cc) LGIA Operating Expenses means all expenses due and payable under the LGIA, including expenses incurred in connection with complying with the LGIA (including affirmative covenants with respect to maintenance of the Projects and the Interconnection Customers Interconnection Facilities, communications with Transmission Provider, insurance, and reporting), plus the Management Fee, but excluding the Construction Costs; provided, that costs relating to the Interconnection Customers Interconnection Facilities shall be allocated in accordance with the Shared Facilities Agreement. (dd) GDPIPD means the Gross Domestic Product Implicit Price Deflator, as published by the Department of Commerce: Bureau of Economic Analysis immediately preceding the applicable date of adjustment, or such other index as mutually agreed upon between the Manager and the CoTenants. (ee) Management Fee has the meaning given in Section 3.6. (ff) Manager means Roadrunner BESS SF LLC, or any successor thereto pursuant to Section 3.5. (gg) Maximum Capacity means, for each Project, the maximum possible Net Output of such Project, as currently set forth on Exhibit A hereto, as such exhibit may be amended from time to time. (hh) MW means a megawatt alternating current or megawatts alternating current, as the context may require. (ii) NERC means the North American Electric Reliability Corporation or its successor organization. (jj) Net Output means, for each Project, the maximum power output of the Project as measured at the Point of Interconnection; provided, however, that, at any time, the Net Output of all Projects shall not exceed the Interconnection Capacity. (kk) Network Upgrades has the meaning given in the LGIA. (ll) Party and Parties have the meanings given in the preamble to this Agreement. (mm) Person means any individual or entity, and the heirs, personal representatives, successors and assigns of such individual or entity where the context so permits. (nn) Project has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (oo) Project Specific Assets means, for each Co-Tenant, any of the assets comprising its respective Project, the corresponding Project Specific Real Property and related Project agreements and contractual arrangements, including any additional facilities that are not and do not become Shared Facilities under the Sharded Facilities Agreement. For the avoidance of doubt, the Project Specific Assets shall exclude the LGIA. (pp) Project Specific Real Property means, for any Project, the real property on which such Project is located. (qq) Prudent Industry Practice means any of the practices, methods, and standards of care, skill, safety and diligence, as the same may change from time to time, but applied in light of the facts known at the time, as are generally applied or utilized under comparable circumstances by reasonably experienced and prudent professionals in respect of the design, development, construction, commissioning, maintenance, financing and operation of electric generating facilities, battery storage facilities and electric generator interconnection facilities located in the United States of America of comparable type and complexity to the Projects and the Shared Facilities. Prudent Industry Practices does not necessarily mean the best practice, method, or standard of care, skill, safety and diligence in all cases, but is instead intended to encompass a range of acceptable practices, methods, and standards. (rr) Point of Interconnection has the meaning given in the LGIA. (ss) Representative has the meaning set forth in Section 2.18. (tt) Shared Facilities has the meaning given in the Shared Facilities Agreement. (uu) Shared Facilities Agreement means (i) the Shared Facilities Agreement, dated of even date herewith, by and among Roadrunner Solar SF LLC and Manager (in its capacity as such), as may be amended, supplemented, or replaced from time-to-time, and (ii) any other agreement pursuant to which one or more Co-Tenants share in the ownership, operation, and right to use any component of the Interconnection Facilities. (vv) Switching Station means the Cochise Substation owned by Transmission Provider, located in Cochise County, Arizona. (ww) Tariff means the document adopted by the utility transmission owner and transmission or interconnection service provider under the LGIA, including Transmission Provider, and any successor thereto (including but not limited to any independent system operator or regional transmission organization established by or with the authorization of the FERC), including any attachments or exhibits referenced therein, as amended from time to time, that contains the scheduling, operating, planning, reliability, and settlement (including registration) policies, rules, guidelines, procedures, standards, and criteria of such interconnection provider, transmission owner or transmission provider. The version of the Tariff in effect at the time of the performance or non-performance of an action shall govern with respect to that action. (xx) Transfer means to grant, sell, assign, set over, deliver, convey, demise, dispose of or otherwise transfer an interest in real property, tangible or intangible assets, whether voluntarily, by operation of law, at judicial sale or otherwise. (yy) Transmission Provider has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (zz) Transmission Providers Interconnection Facilities has the meaning given in the LGIA. (aaa) Undivided Interest has the meaning given in Section 2.1.
Article II. CO-TENANCY RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS 2.1 Declaration of Intention. The Parties hereby declare that their relationship in and to the LGIA and the Interconnection Customers rights and obligations thereunder is and will be that of tenants-in-common, and that each Co-Tenant will have an undivided interest (Undivided Interest) in the LGIA and the Interconnection Customers rights and obligations thereunder, expressly subject, however, to the terms, conditions, limitations and requirements set forth in this Agreement. Nothing contained in this Agreement will be deemed to constitute the Parties as partners or joint venturers. The Parties acknowledge and agree that the Roadrunner PV Project and the Roadrunner BESS Project will be treated as a single Project under the LGIA. 2.2 Use of LGIA. The LGIA shall be held and used solely to permit the interconnection of electricity generated, stored, or discharged by or on behalf of a Project owned by a Co-Tenant (or by such Co-Tenants successors or assigns) at the Switching Station. Subject to Section 2.3, each Co-Tenant shall have an undivided ownership interest as tenant-in-common in the rights and obligations of the Interconnection Customer and the LGIA equal to its Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest and shall possess an undivided right to enjoy all of such interest as an Interconnection Customer under the LGIA. In the event of a conflict between the terms of the LGIA and this Agreement, the terms of the LGIA shall prevail. 2.3 Maximum Capacity. No Co-Tenant shall interconnect its respective Project to the Point of Interconnection to the extent such interconnection will result in such Co-Tenant having a Project with a Net Output in excess of its Maximum Capacity, and to the extent that conditions exist that result in a Co-Tenant generating or discharging energy from its respective Project in excess of its Maximum Capacity, then such Co-Tenant shall curtail the operation of its Project so as not to exceed its Maximum Capacity unless such Co-Tenant receives written approval from the other Co-Tenants to generate or discharge in excess of its Maximum Capacity. At any time, the aggregate Net Outputs of Roadrunner PV and Roadrunner BESS shall not exceed the Interconnection Capacity. 2.4 Curtailment. In the event of any curtailment of interconnection services at the direction of Transmission Provider, such curtailment shall be allocated among the Co-Tenants in accordance with the Shared Facilities Agreement. 2.5 LGIA Expenses. (a) Construction Costs. Excluding Construction Costs for Project Specific Assets, Roadrunner PV and Roadrunner BESS shall be solely responsible, on a pro rata basis, for the payment of the Construction Costs required to design, engineer and construct the Transmission Providers Interconnection Facilities, Network Upgrades, and Interconnection Customers Interconnection Facilities identified in the LGIA that are necessary for the interconnection of the Projects; provided, that Construction Costs required to design, engineer and construct the Shared Facilities shall be allocated in accordance with the Shared Facilities Agreement. For the avoidance of doubt, the pro rata allocation of Construction Costs under this Section 2.5(a) shall be calculated for each of Roadrunner PV and Roadrunner BESS as a percentage based on the Maximum Capacity of its Project divided by the aggregate Maximum Capacities of Roadrunner PV Project and Roadrunner BESS Project. (b) LGIA Operating Expenses. Each Co-Tenant shall be responsible for the payment of its pro rata share of the LGIA Operating Expenses in accordance with the Co-Tenancy Percentage Interests of the Co-Tenants with Projects that have been interconnected to the Switching Station and are delivering energy as of the time of such determination of LGIA Operating Expenses. (c) LGIA Liabilities. Except as set forth in this Section 2.5 with respect to Construction Costs and LGIA Operating Expenses, any damages, liabilities, claims, judgments, liens, penalties, costs and expenses charged or incurred under the LGIA (LGIA Liabilities) shall be borne pro rata by the Co-Tenants, including by Co-Tenants that have not yet obtained a Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest; provided, that any LGIA Liabilities incurred as the result of the actions or inactions of one or more Co-Tenants shall be paid solely by such Co-Tenants. (d) Payment of LGIA Expenses. The Manager shall, as authorized agent for each Co-Tenant, administer the collection and payment of the LGIA Operating Expenses, Construction Costs, and other amounts due from the Interconnection Customer under the LGIA, except as may otherwise be provided in the Shared Facilities Agreement. Each Co-Tenant shall pay each invoice it receives from the Manager for its share, determined pursuant to this Section 2.5, of the LGIA costs promptly upon receipt of written notice thereof, but in any event within thirty (30) days of such receipt or such earlier time as required by the LGIA. 2.6 Changes in Maximum Capacity. Subject to Section 2.3: (a) The Maximum Capacity of any Project shall be increased only upon receipt by such Projects Co-Tenant of (i) written consent to such increase provided by the other Co-Tenant, such consent to be provided in each such Co-Tenants sole discretion not to be unreasonably withheld, (ii) all consents required under the Shared Facilities Agreement, (iii) an approved Material Modification request (as defined in the LGIA) or an executed and effective new or amended LGIA, if required, to reflect an increase in Interconnection Capacity and (iv) any other necessary consents by the Transmission Provider; and (b) The Maximum Capacity of any Project shall be decreased only upon receipt by such Projects Co-Tenant of written consent to such decrease provided by, (i) if required under the LGIA, the Transmission Provider, and (ii) each other Co-Tenant, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld; provided however, that, absent the consent of the other Co-Tenant, any such decrease in Maximum Capacity shall not decrease or change such Co-Tenants responsibility for payment of LGIA Operating Expenses based on its initial Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest, as set forth on Exhibit A hereto, including payment of LGIA Operating Expenses under Section 2.5. 2.7 Liquidated Damages; Credits; Refunds. To the extent that the Manager receives any damages, credits or refunds pursuant to the LGIA, the Manager shall promptly remit such damages, credits or refunds to the Co-Tenants according to the Co-Tenancy Percentage Interests of the Co-Tenants with Projects that have been interconnected to the Switching Station and are delivering energy as of the time such damages, credits or refunds accrued (unless such damages, credits or refunds accrue to a specific Co-Tenant, in which event the Manager shall promptly remit them to such Co-Tenant, including damages, credits or refunds regarding the Construction Costs); provided, that, any refunds paid under the LGIA for facilities financed solely by a Co-Tenant(s) shall be refunded only to such Co-Tenant(s). 2.8 Joint and Several Liability. Each Co-Tenant shall be jointly and severally liable for (i) any payments due under the LGIA imposed on the Interconnection Customer and (ii) the performance of the obligations and duties imposed on the Interconnection Customer by the LGIA; provided, however, that each Party shall be severally, and not, jointly liable for all other obligations hereunder. 2.9 Projected Capacity. Each Co-Tenant shall notify the Manager and the other Co-Tenants in writing, no later than ten (10) Business Days following the Effective Date, of the planned Net Output of its Project, provided that, subject to Section 2.3, each Co-Tenants Net Output is subject to Section 2.3 and may not exceed such Co-Tenants Maximum Capacity. 2.10 Indemnity. (a) To the fullest extent permitted by Laws, each Party (an Indemnifying Party) shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless each other Party (an Indemnified Party) from and against any and all losses (including all lost revenues under applicable power purchase agreements or other agreements for the sale of products generated or provided by the Projects), damages, liabilities, claims, judgments, liens, penalties, costs and expenses, including reasonable attorneys and consultants fees (collectively, Claims), which may be imposed upon or incurred by such Indemnified Party or asserted against such Indemnified Party in connection with any breach by the Indemnifying Party of this Agreement or the LGIA. The indemnification provided under this Section 2.10(a) will not apply to the extent any such losses are caused by the gross negligence, willful misconduct or intentionally wrongful acts or omissions of any of the applicable Indemnified Parties. (b) In the event that an Indemnifying Party is obligated to indemnify, reimburse and hold an Indemnified Party harmless under this Article II, the amount owing to the Indemnified Party will be the amount of such Indemnified Partys reasonable, documented actual out-of-pocket loss net of any insurance or other recovery (including deductibles but net of any reasonable third party out of pocket costs and expenses associated with such recoveries), it being understood and agreed that each Indemnified Party, as applicable, shall use its commercially reasonable efforts to seek insurance recoveries in respect of losses to be indemnified hereunder. If any insurance proceeds or other recoveries from third parties are actually realized (in each case calculated net of the reasonable third party out of pocket costs and expenses associated with such recoveries) by an Indemnified Party subsequent to the receipt by such Indemnified Party of an indemnification payment hereunder in respect of the claims to which such insurance proceedings or third party recoveries relate, the Indemnified Party, as applicable, shall hold such amounts in trust and appropriate refunds shall be made promptly to the indemnifying Party regarding the amount of such indemnification payment. 2.11 Taxes. Each Co-Tenant shall directly pay all of its real and personal property taxes and assessments, general or special, levied against such Co-Tenants Project, except for its pro rata share of any taxes or assessments that are LGIA Operating Expenses, which it shall pay to the Manager. All such taxes and assessments shall be paid before delinquency and before any fine, interest or penalty shall become due or be imposed for their non-payment; provided if a Co-Tenant in good faith contests or disputes such taxes or assessments and furnishes to the other Co-Tenant a bond or other acceptable security in an amount sufficient to discharge all such contested taxes or assessments, such Co-Tenant will not be in default under this Section 2.11 for failing to timely pay such contested taxes or assessments. 2.12 Operation and Management. (a) Each Co-Tenant shall operate and maintain its Project Specific Assets acting as a prudent operator and manager and otherwise (i) in accordance with the terms of the LGIA, (ii) in accordance with Prudent Industry Practices, (iii) in compliance with all applicable Laws, including but not limited to the Federal Power Act, as amended (FPA), and all rules, regulations, and orders issued by the FERC pursuant to the FPA to the extent applicable, (iv) in compliance with the Tariff, including the rules, protocols, procedures and standards attached thereto, as the same may be amended from time to time and approved by FERC to the extent applicable, and (v) in compliance with the rules, protocols, procedures and standards of NERC. (b) Each Co-Tenant shall comply with its obligations under the LGIA, including with respect to its obligation to fund the LGIA Operating Expenses. Each Co-Tenant shall obtain and maintain status as an exempt wholesale generator under applicable Law, and shall obtain and maintain FERC authorization to sell energy at wholesale at market-based rates. (c) Each Co-Tenant shall cooperate with and timely respond to Manager as agent for the Co-Tenants under the LGIA, and shall provide Manager with such information as may be required by Manager to comply with the Interconnection Customers obligations under the LGIA and Managers obligations hereunder. (d) With respect to jointly held assets, the Co-Tenants may delegate to the Manager some or all of their respective obligations under this Agreement. 2.13 Events of Default. The following shall each constitute a default by a Party under this Agreement (each an Event of Default): (a) Payment. A Party fails to pay when due any amounts required to be paid by such Party under this Agreement, and such failure to pay is not cured within fifteen (15) days following written notice from another Party specifying the amount to be paid; provided, however, that such period will be extended for so long as the allegedly defaulting Party is disputing in good faith such amount pursuant to the procedures set forth in Section 2.18. (b) Other Defaults. A Party fails to cure any other failure to perform a material obligation under this Agreement within thirty (30) days following written notice from any other Party specifying the nature of the failure to perform, provided that if the default is not reasonably capable of being cured within thirty (30) days, then the default will be deemed cured if the defaulting Party commences, diligently pursues, and completes action that remedies the default within ninety (90) days of receipt of such notice. (c) LGIA or Shared Facilities Agreement. (i) A Co-Tenant or such Co-Tenants Lessor that is a Co-Tenant under the Shared Facilities Agreement breaches, or causes the breach of, the LGIA or the Shared Facilities Agreement, and such breach material adversely affects any of the Shared Facilities, this Agreement, the LGIA, or any non-defaulting Co-Tenants Project, and such defaulting Co-Tenant or such Lessor fails to cure such breach within the time permitted by such agreement. Each of the Co-Tenants agrees to provide a copy of any notice of default received by it or its applicable Lessor to the Manager, the other Co-Tenants under the LGIA and the co-tenants under the Shared Facilities Agreement within twenty-four (24) hours of receiving such notice of default, regardless of the party or the contract that is alleged to be in default in the notice. (ii) Manager causes a breach of a material obligation in the LGIA or the Shared Facilities Agreement and fails to cure same within the time period provided by such agreements, as applicable. (d) Bankruptcy. If a Co-Tenant is adjudicated as bankrupt, becomes insolvent, enters into an arrangement or composition with such Co-Tenants creditors, suffers permanent or temporary court-appointed receivership of substantially all of such Co-Tenant's property, makes a general assignment for the benefit of creditors, or files a voluntary bankruptcy petition, or, if a petition or an answer is filed proposing the adjudication of such Co-Tenant as bankrupt, when such Co-Tenant shall consent to the filing thereof or sixty (60) days after the filing thereof unless the same shall have been discharged, opposed, or denied prior thereto. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the foregoing notice of default shall not be effective, and the period of time within which the defaulting Co-Tenant may cure the noticed default shall not commence to run, unless and until a copy of said notice of default is provided to any Financing Party who has a security interest in the defaulting Co-Tenants Undivided Interest in the LGIA, and who has given the Manager notice of such security interest. The non-defaulting Co-Tenants shall accept curative performance from any such Financing Parties within the time periods provided for in Section 4.2(b). For purposes of this Section 2.13, material adversely affects includes any adverse impact (or reasonably expected adverse impact) to a non-defaulting Co-Tenants or its applicable Affiliates ability to transmit energy to the grid. 2.14 Remedies. Subject to the last sentence of Section 5.8, in addition to all other remedies permitted by Law or under this Agreement (all of which shall be cumulative), following an Event of Default, each non-defaulting Party shall have the right, but not the obligation, to perform the obligations of the defaulting Party, and the defaulting Party shall reimburse the performing Parties for their expenses which they incurred in rendering the performance, plus interest at the Interest Rate. The failure of any non-defaulting Party to exercise a remedy shall not constitute a waiver of any default or a waiver of future defaults, nor shall it constitute a waiver of the right to exercise any remedy. 2.15 Disconnection. At the direction of Transmission Provider, or following an Event of Default by a Co-Tenant, the Manager shall have the right to disconnect the defaulting Co-Tenants Project in accordance with the Shared Facilities Agreement. 2.16 Bankruptcy Provisions. (a) Assumption. In the event a Party in Bankruptcy seeks to assume, or assume and assign, this Agreement pursuant to 11 U.S.C. § 365, such Party shall at the time of such assumption cure all defaults, or provide to the non-bankrupt Parties adequate assurance that it or its assignee will promptly cure all defaults under this Agreement. The Parties agree that the following will constitute adequate assurance of a prompt cure under 11 U.S.C. § 365: (i) The payment, on the date of entry of an order by the bankruptcy court approving the assumption, or assumption and assignment, by the Party in Bankruptcy or its assignee of, sufficient funds to the non-bankrupt Parties to fully cure all financial defaults under this Agreement; and (ii) The provision by the Party in Bankruptcy or its assignee of such insurance, bonding, or other financial commitments which, in the reasonable opinion of the non-bankrupt Parties, will adequately assure the future performance of the non-bankrupt Parties under this Agreement. (b) Rejection. In the event a Party in Bankruptcy seeks and receives court permission to reject this Agreement pursuant to 11 U.S.C. § 365, its interest in this Agreement and the LGIA shall terminate on entry of an order by the court in the Bankruptcy approving such rejection, and its interest in this Agreement shall be allocated to the remaining Co-Tenant. 2.17 Equitable Relief. The Parties agree that damages may be an inadequate remedy for a breach by the Manager or any other Party of its respective obligations under this Agreement, and that each Party shall be entitled to seek injunctive and other equitable relief, including specific performance, against any other Party or the Manager to prevent or eliminate such default. 2.18 Dispute Resolution. (a) Submission. In the event any Party has a dispute, or asserts a claim, that arises out of or in connection with this Agreement or the LGIA, such Party shall provide the other Parties with written notice of the dispute or claim. Each Party shall appoint one (1) person to coordinate with the other Party regarding the performance of this Agreement (each a Representative and collectively the Representatives). If any dispute arises with respect to either Partys performance under this Agreement, the Representatives shall meet to attempt to resolve such dispute, either in person or by telephone, within five (5) Business Days after the written request of either Representative. Except as otherwise provided hereunder, if the Representatives are unable to resolve such dispute, a senior officer of each Co-Tenant shall meet, either in person or by telephone, within ten (10) Business Days after either Representative provides written notice that the Representatives have been unable to resolve such dispute, to attempt to resolve the dispute. (b) Any disputes arising out of, in connection with or with respect to this Agreement, the subject matter hereof, the performance or non-performance of any obligation hereunder, that cannot be resolved in accordance with this Section 2.18, shall be adjudicated in a state or federal court of competent civil jurisdiction sitting in the State of New York. Each of the Parties irrevocably consents and agrees that any legal action or proceedings with respect to this Agreement may be brought in the courts of the State of New York or the United States of America for the District of New York having subject matter jurisdiction and, by execution and delivery of this Agreement and such other documents executed in connection herewith, each Party (i) accepts the exclusive jurisdiction of the aforesaid courts, (ii) irrevocably agrees to be bound by any final judgment (after any and all appeals) of any such court with respect to such documents, (iii) irrevocably waives, to the fullest extent permitted by law, any objection to the laying of venue of any suit, action or proceedings with respect to such documents brought in any such court, and further irrevocably waives, to the fullest extent permitted by law, any claim that any such suit, action or proceedings brought in any such court has been brought in any inconvenient forum, (iv) agrees that service of process in any such action may be effected by mailing a copy thereof by registered or certified mail (or any substantially similar form of mail), postage prepaid, to such Party at its address set forth below, or at such other address of which the other Party hereto has been notified and (v) agrees that nothing herein will affect the right to effect service of process in any other manner permitted by law or limit the right to bring any suit, action or proceeding in any other jurisdiction. 2.19 Effect of Force Majeure. No Party shall be considered to be in default with respect to any obligation hereunder, (including obligations under Article 4), other than the obligation to pay money when due, if prevented from fulfilling such obligation by Force Majeure. A Party unable to fulfill any obligation hereunder (other than an obligation to pay money when due) by reason of Force Majeure shall give notice and the full particulars of such Force Majeure to the other Party in writing or by telephone as soon as reasonably possible after the occurrence of the cause relied upon. Telephone notices given pursuant to this article shall be confirmed in writing as soon as reasonably possible and shall specifically state full particulars of the Force Majeure, the time and date when the Force Majeure occurred and when the Force Majeure is reasonably expected to cease. The Party affected shall exercise due diligence to remove such disability with reasonable dispatch, but shall not be required to accede or agree to any provision not satisfactory to it in order to settle and terminate a strike or other labor disturbance. For the avoidance of doubt, economic hardship is not considered a Force Majeure event. 2.20 Notice of Default. Each Co-Tenant and the Manager shall promptly provide written notice to the other Parties upon receiving notice of, or otherwise discovering, any default or potential default under this Agreement or the LGIA or receiving any other notice under the LGIA. 2.21 Performance under LGIA. Each Co-Tenant shall perform its obligations under the LGIA and hereunder as the holder of an undivided ownership interest as tenant-in-common in the amount of its Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest of the Interconnection Capacity, including, but not limited to, payment of insurance premiums, payment of taxes, payment of any security required under the LGIA, and coverage of indemnity obligations arising hereunder and thereunder. 2.22 Insurance. The Co-Tenants shall jointly procure and maintain throughout the term of this Agreement the insurance required in order to comply with the LGIA. Responsibility for the payment of premiums associated therewith shall be satisfied through the pro-rata share obligations specified in Section 2.5. 2.23 FERC Filing. The Co-Tenants agree that (a) the Manager shall, if required pursuant to FERCs regulations or other applicable Law, file this Agreement with FERC under Section 205 of the Federal Power Act (the FERC Filing), and (b) in connection with the FERC Filing, each other then-existing Co-Tenant shall execute and file (or execute and cause the Manager to file on its behalf) a notice of concurrence to this Agreement with FERC concurrent with the FERC Filing. The Manager shall not make the FERC Filing unless each Co-Tenant has reviewed and approved the form and content of the FERC Filing, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld, denied or delayed. Any new Co-Tenant shall file a notice of concurrence to this Agreement upon becoming a Co-Tenant to this Agreement. Article III. MANAGER 3.1 Appointment of Manager; Manager Services. Each Co-Tenant hereby appoints the Manager to act as its agent and representative for all purposes under the LGIA, and, unless otherwise agreed by the Co-Tenants, the Manager shall have the power to exercise and shall exercise any and all of the rights of the Interconnection Customer under the LGIA and shall coordinate compliance with the LGIA by the Co-Tenants; provided that the Manager may not terminate, amend or Transfer the LGIA or waive any material rights of the Co-Tenants under the LGIA or initiate or settle any dispute resolution under the LGIA, without the prior, unanimous written consent of the Co-Tenants. In addition, each Co-Tenant specifically authorizes the Manager to negotiate and, with the Co-Tenants prior written consent, execute on its behalf and on behalf of the Interconnection Customer, and agrees to be bound by the terms of, a retail electricity service agreement; provided that, to the extent that the Manager acts as agent for the Co-Tenants under any such agreement, the Manager may not terminate, amend or Transfer any such agreement or waive any material rights of the Co-Tenants under any such agreement or initiate or settle any dispute resolution under any such agreement, without the prior, unanimous written consent of the Co-Tenants. 3.2 Communications. The Manager shall be the single point of contact between the Co-Tenants and Transmission Provider, and shall be responsible for all administrative obligations of the Interconnection Customer under the LGIA, including billing, issuing payments, providing notices and communicating with, and receiving instructions from, Transmission Provider with respect to the Projects and the LGIA. The Manager shall, promptly upon receipt, provide to each Co-Tenant a copy of any notices or other material communications received by it under the LGIA. 3.3 Indemnification of Manager. Each Co-Tenant shall, pro rata in accordance with its Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest, defend, indemnify and hold harmless the Manager and its employees and agents, from any claim, loss, liability or damage incurred by reason of any act performed or omitted to be performed by it in its reasonable judgment, in good faith, or in reasonable reliance on advice of the Managers attorneys or accountants, in connection with the LGIA or this Agreement (other than acts or omissions constituting a material breach by the Manager of this Agreement or the fraud, willful misconduct, or gross negligence of the Manager), including reasonable attorneys fees incurred by it in connection with the defense of any action based on any such alleged act or omission. The Manager shall specifically be indemnified by the Co-Tenants (pro rata in accordance with their Co-Tenancy Percentage Interests) and held harmless from any and all actions taken by the Manager in its reasonable judgment, in good faith, or in reasonable reliance on advice of the Managers attorneys or accountants, and otherwise in accordance with this Agreement, and shall be reimbursed by the Co-Tenants (pro rata in accordance with their Co-Tenancy Percentage Interests) for costs, which arise in connection with the LGIA or this Agreement (other than costs resulting from a material breach by the Manager of this Agreement or the fraud, willful misconduct, or gross negligence of the Manager). 3.4 Books and Records; Reporting Requirements. (a) Maintenance or Records. The Manager shall maintain books and records in sufficient detail to verify amounts due and payable hereunder for a period of not less than three (3) years after the end of the calendar month to which they relate, and all such books and records shall be available for inspection and/or copying by each Co-Tenant or its authorized representative at the cost and expense of such Co-Tenant and at reasonable times during regular business hours, upon reasonable notice to the Manager. (b) Provision of Records. The Manager shall, from time to time or at the reasonable request of the Co-Tenants or their Financing Parties, provide reports to the Co-Tenants and their Financing Parties sufficient to keep the Co-Tenants and their Financing Parties reasonably apprised as to significant matters concerning the LGIA, the Construction Costs and the LGIA Operating Expenses. 3.5 Replacement of Manager. (a) Provided that a replacement Manager has been selected by the Co-Tenants (excluding any Co-Tenant that is then acting as the Manager), the Manager may be removed by the vote of a majority of the Co-Tenants, acting reasonably and excluding the Co-Tenant that is then acting as the Manager, if Manager (i) breaches any material provision of this Agreement or fails to cure any such breach, action or omission within thirty (30) days after receiving notice thereof from any Co-Tenant (or, if such cure cannot reasonably be completed within such thirty (30) day period, Manager fails to undertake and promptly cure upon receipt of such notice or fails to give adequate assurances to the Co-Tenants that such breach or action will be so cured with all reasonable speed, not to exceed another thirty (30) days), (ii) engages in gross negligence or willful misconduct in the performance of its obligations hereunder, (iii) dissolves, liquidates or terminates its corporate or limited liability company existence, or (iv) is a Co-Tenant and such Co-Tenant sells, assigns, or otherwise transfers its rights or interests in the Shared Assets or this Agreement. During such times, if any, as: (1) the circumstances described in clause (i) or (ii) above exist, and (2) an Event of Default hereunder is ongoing with respect to a Co-Tenant affiliated with the Manager, the non-defaulting Co-Tenants may unilaterally remove the Manager. Any Co-Tenant seeking to remove the Manager pursuant to this Section 3.5(a) shall provide notice to the other Co-Tenants of such removal at the same time as notice is given to the Manager. (b) Provided that a replacement Manager has been selected by the Co-Tenants, the Manager may be removed without cause upon the written consent of all Co-Tenants. (c) In exercising their rights under this Section 3.5, the Co-Tenants shall ensure that any replacement Manager selected by the Co-Tenants will be appointed as the replacement Manager under the Shared Facilities Agreement such that any Manager under this Agreement will continue to be the Manager under the Shared Facilities Agreement. (d) The new Manager shall execute a joinder to this Agreement, which shall bind such new Manager to the provisions of this Agreement, including as set forth in Section 2.1, and provide its contact information pursuant to Section 5.1. 3.6 Management Fee. In consideration of the services provided by Manager hereunder, the Manager shall be paid an aggregate annual fee in the amount of Twelve Thousand Dollars ($12,000) (the Management Fee), payable monthly, in advance, in equal monthly installments equal to One Thousand Dollars ($1,000), beginning on the date hereof and ending on the termination of this Agreement or the replacement of the Manager. The Management Fee shall be increased (but not decreased) annually for each calendar year after the Effective Date by the percentage change in the GDPIPD, if increased, during such calendar year. The Management Fee shall be allocated to the Co-Tenants in accordance with Section 2.5 as an LGIA Operating Expense. 3.7 Discrimination. Other than as expressly permitted under Sections 2.4 and 2.15, the Manager shall not Discriminate in providing services or otherwise performing its obligations hereunder among the Co-Tenants. As used herein, Discriminate means a failure by the Manager to provide services hereunder in a manner that treats alike each of the Co-Tenants under substantially similar conditions, and for which dissimilar treatment is not otherwise justified as necessary in accordance with Prudent Industry Practices. 3.8 Performance. The Manager shall perform its obligations under this Agreement (a) in accordance with the terms of the LGIA, (b) in accordance with Prudent Industry Practices, (c) in compliance with all applicable Laws, including but not limited to the FPA, and all rules, regulations, and orders issued by the FERC pursuant to the FPA to the extent applicable, (d) in compliance with both the Transmission Provider, including the rules, protocols, procedures and standards attached thereto, as the same may be amended from time to time and approved by FERC to the extent applicable, (e) in compliance with the rules, protocols, procedures and standards of NERC, and (f) without causing a material adverse effect on any Project, the performance by a Co-Tenant under a power purchase agreement, the LGIA, or the Shared Facilities Agreement. 3.9 Termination of LGIA. In the event that Transmission Provider seeks to terminate the LGIA and any Co-Tenant objects to such termination, the Co-Tenants and Manager shall cooperate and take such joint actions as may be reasonably necessary or advisable, in each case, to prevent such termination, including submitting a written objection to Transmission Provider and/or filing a protest or complaint with FERC, if applicable. Article IV. TRANSFERABILITY 4.1 Transfers. (a) Transfer by Co-Tenant. Except as set forth in Section 4.1(c), no Co-Tenant may Transfer its rights in its Undivided Interest or any of its rights or interests under this Agreement without obtaining the prior written consent of the other Co-Tenants, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed. Any Transfer of all or a portion of a Co-Tenants Undivided Interest or any other rights and interests in this Agreement shall require that, as of the effective date of such Transfer, (i) the transferee agrees in writing to bound by all the terms and conditions of this Agreement in the place and stead of the transferring Co-Tenant, including any obligation of the transferring Co-Tenant under this Agreement or the LGIA, as applicable, (ii) all required Governmental Approvals have been obtained (if and to the extent necessary) and (iii) any and all necessary Financing Parties and other third party consents to such assignment are obtained. If the procedures provided in this Section 4.1(a) are complied with, such Co-Tenant shall be released from any further obligations hereunder arising from and after the effective date of such Transfer. (b) Transfer by Manager. Except as set forth in this Agreement, Manager may not Transfer all or any part of its rights or interests under this Agreement without the prior written consent granted by the Co-Tenants (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed), and the applicable transferee has assumed, in writing, all of the duties and obligations of the Manager under this Agreement, including any obligation of transferring Manager under this Agreement. If the procedures provided in this Section 4.1(b) are complied with, Manager shall be released from any further obligations hereunder arising from and after the effective date of such Transfer. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, Manager shall be permitted to perform its operations, repair and maintenance obligations herein through subcontractors engaged by Manager, provided that no such subcontracting arrangement shall release or modify Managers obligations herein (c) No Consent Required. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the Transfer of any direct or indirect interest in the membership interests in any Party in connection with any sale, merger, reorganization, foreclosure by Financing Parties or tax equity financing or refinancing shall be expressly permitted and shall not require the consent or approval of any other Party hereunder, provided that after any such event, the Party shall remain obligated for its duties and obligations hereunder. (d) No Transfer. Any attempted or purported Transfer of any interest in the Undivided Interest or this Agreement, made other than in accordance with this Section 4.1, either voluntarily or by operation of law, will be null and void and of no force or effect whatsoever. 4.2 Right to Encumber. (a) Right to Encumber. The Manager and each Co-Tenant specifically agrees that any Co-Tenant may at any time pledge, collaterally assign, encumber, or grant a security interest in its own Undivided Interest and in its rights under this Agreement to any Financing Parties. Each Co-Tenant shall, at any time and from time to time during the term of this Agreement, after receipt of a written request by any other Co-Tenant, execute and deliver to the requesting Co-Tenant and such Co-Tenants Financing Parties, as designated in such request, such estoppel certificates, opinions, officer certificates and consents as may be reasonably requested thereby. (b) Pledge, Collateral Assignment or Encumbrance. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, to the extent a Co-Tenant pledges, collaterally assigns or encumbers its Undivided Interest and its rights under this Agreement as provided above, the Co-Tenants expressly agree between themselves and for the benefit of any Financing Parties that (i) upon the occurrence of a default by a Co-Tenant hereunder, any non-defaulting Co-Tenant declaring the default shall also provide written notice to the defaulting Co-Tenants Financing Parties (of which the Co-Tenants have notice) of such default (and accept such Financing Parties cure of such default), and (ii) each Financing Party shall have the same period after receipt of such notice of default as is given to the defaulting Co-Tenant under this Agreement to cure, or cause to be cured, the default described therein, as is given to the defaulting Co-Tenant, plus, in each instance, the following additional time periods: (A) thirty (30) days in the event of any monetary default; and (B) sixty (60) days in the event of any non-monetary default. The Parties agree that no Financing Party shall be obligated to perform any obligation or be deemed to incur any liability or obligation provided in this Agreement on either Partys part or shall have any obligation or liability to either Party with respect to this Agreement except to the extent any Financing Party has assumed a Partys obligations under this Agreement. In the event that any mortgage, deed of trust or other security interest in this Agreement or in any Co-Tenants Undivided Interest, or any portion thereof, is entered into by any Co-Tenant, this Agreement shall not be modified, amended, cancelled, terminated or released without the prior written consent of such Financing Party, not to be unreasonably withheld conditioned, or delayed; provided that the consent of a defaulting Co-Tenants Financing Party shall not be necessary for any non-defaulting Co-Tenant to exercise any termination rights granted herein after the expiration of all applicable notice and cure periods. (c) Expenses. All reasonable expenses, including reasonable attorneys fees, incurred by the Manager or any other Co-Tenants in connection with the actual or proposed pledge, collateral assignment, encumbrance, or grant of a security interest in another Co-Tenants Undivided Interest and its rights under this Agreement to a Financing Party, shall be paid or reimbursed by the assigning/borrowing Co-Tenant to the Manager and other Co-Tenants upon request therefor. (d) Assignment by the Manager. The Manager may not assign, pledge or otherwise transfer this Agreement without the prior written consent of each other Co-Tenant, which may be withheld in such Co-Tenants sole and absolute discretion, provided however, such restriction on assignment as a result of an upstream merger, acquisition, sale or other institutional reorganization of the Manager or its Affiliates; provided further, if such latter event occurs the Co-Tenants shall have the removal right contained in Section 3.5. Article V. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 5.1 Notices. Any notice, demand, or communication required or permitted to be given by any provision of this Agreement shall be deemed to have been sufficiently given or served for all purposes if delivered personally or by telecopy to the Party or to an executive officer of the Party to whom the same is directed or, if sent by registered or certified mail, postage and charges prepaid, addressed to the Partys address, as appropriate, which is set forth below or to such other address as a Party shall advise the other Parties from time to time in writing, and shall be deemed effective one day following such personal delivery, date of telecopy or delivery by registered or certified mail. If to Roadrunner PV: c/o Clenera, LLC 999 W. Main Street, Suite 800 Boise, ID 83702 Attention: Admin Dept. Email: clenera.notices@clenera.com
If to Roadrunner BESS: c/o Clenera, LLC 999 W. Main Street, Suite 800 Boise, ID 83702 Attention: Admin Dept. Email: clenera.notices@clenera.com
If to Manager: c/o Clenera, LLC 999 W. Main Street, Suite 800 Boise, ID 83702 Attention: Admin Dept. Email: clenera.notices@clenera.com
5.2 Governing Law. This Agreement shall in all respects be governed by and construed and enforced in accordance with the internal laws of the State of New York, without regard to its choice of law provisions. 5.3 Entire Agreement. This Agreement is governed by the Laws of the State of New York, excluding any choice of law rules that would direct application of Laws of another jurisdiction. Each Party hereby irrevocably and unconditionally submits to the exclusive jurisdiction of any State court or federal court of the United States of America, in either case, sitting in courts of the State of New York and of the Federal District Courts in the Southern District of New York, and waives, to the fullest extent legally permissible, any objection which it may now or hereafter have to the personal jurisdiction of such courts or venue of any proceeding arising out of or relating to this Agreement in such courts and any defense of an inconvenient forum to the maintenance of such action or proceeding in such courts. IN ADDITION, EACH PARTY HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW, ANY RIGHT IT MAY HAVE TO A TRIAL BY JURY IN RESPECT OF ANY LITIGATION DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY ARISING OUT OF, UNDER OR IN CONNECTION WITH THIS AGREEMENT. 5.4 Interpretation. All personal pronouns used in this Agreement, whether used in the masculine, feminine or neuter gender, shall include all other genders; the singular shall include the plural; and the plural shall include the singular. Titles of articles and sections in this Agreement are for convenience only and neither limit nor amplify the provisions of this Agreement. All references in this Agreement to articles, sections, subsections or paragraphs shall refer to articles, sections, subsections and paragraphs of this Agreement, unless specific reference is made to the articles, sections or other subdivisions of another document or instrument. The word including shall mean including without limitation. This Agreement shall not be interpreted in favor of any Party by virtue of said Party not having prepared this Agreement. The unenforceability, invalidity, or illegality of any provision of this Agreement shall not affect or impair the continuing enforceability or validity of any other part, all of which shall survive and be valid and enforceable. 5.5 Waiver. No consent or waiver, express or implied by any Party hereto, to or of any breach or default by the other in the performance by the other of its obligations hereunder shall be deemed or construed to be a consent or waiver to or of any other breach or default in the performance by such other Party of the same or any other obligations of such Party hereunder. Failure on the part of any Party hereto to complain of any act or failure to act of any other Party, or to declare such other Party in default, irrespective of how long such failure continues, shall not constitute a waiver of such Party of its rights hereunder. 5.6 Third Party Beneficiaries. This Agreement and the terms and provisions hereof are solely and exclusively for the benefit of the Parties hereto and, solely to the extent expressly provided herein, their respective Financing Parties. No other Person may rely on any of the provisions herein contained or lay claim to any of the rights of the Parties hereto. 5.7 Counterparts; Facsimile Signatures. This Agreement may be executed in counterparts each of which when so executed and delivered shall be deemed to be an original and all of which together shall constitute one instrument. Signatures delivered by facsimile, email or other electronic means shall be binding upon the Parties hereto with the same force and effect as original signatures. 5.8 Amendments; Term. This Agreement shall not be amended except by the written agreement of the Manager and the Co-Tenants; provided, however, that Managers consent is not required for any amendment hereof so long as its rights and obligations are not adversely affected thereby. No Party may amend the LGIA except by the written consent of each of the Co-Tenants. The Manager shall provide to each of the Co-Tenants a copy of the final amendment to the LGIA permitted pursuant to this Section 5.8. This Agreement shall be in effect for so long as the LGIA is in effect. 5.9 Further Assurances. Upon the reasonable request of any Party at any time after the Effective Date, the other Parties shall forthwith execute and deliver such further instruments of assignment, transfer, conveyance, endorsement, direction or authorization and other documents as the requesting Party or its or their counsel may reasonably request in order to effectuate the purposes of this Agreement. Each Party agrees to reasonably cooperate with the other Parties in assisting it to comply with the terms of this Agreement, including, but not limited to, assistance in obtaining consents, waivers, authorizations, waivers, authorizations, orders and/or approvals of third parties. 5.10 Severability. Any provision of this Agreement that is prohibited or unenforceable in any jurisdiction shall, as to that jurisdiction, be ineffective to the extent of that prohibition or unenforceability without invalidating the remaining provisions hereof or affecting the validity or enforceability of that provision in any other jurisdiction. 5.11 Successors and Assigns. Except as otherwise permitted herein, no Party may assign its rights or obligations under this Agreement without each other Partys prior written consent, which consent may not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed. This Agreement will be binding on, and inure to the benefit of, the Parties and their successors and permitted assigns. 5.12 WAIVER OF RIGHT TO PARTITION. THE CO-TENANTS WILL NOT HAVE AND HEREBY WAIVE THE RIGHT TO PARTITION ALL OR ANY PORTION OF THE SHARED ASSETS, OR TO MAKE APPLICATION TO ANY COURT OR AUTHORITY OR TO COMMENCE OR PROSECUTE ANY ACTION OR PROCEEDING FOR PARTITION OF THE SHARED ASSETS. EACH CO-TENANT WILL BE ENTITLED TO A DECREE OR ORDER RESTRAINING OR ENJOINING SUCH PARTITION, APPLICATION, ACTION OR PROCEEDING UPON ANY BREACH OF THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION 5.12. THE CO-TENANTS ACKNOWLEDGE AND AGREE THAT THEY HAVE BEEN PAID FULL CONSIDERATION FOR THE WAIVER PROVIDED IN THIS SECTION 5.12. [Signature Page Follows]
Page 24 of 20
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties hereto have executed this Agreement as of the date first written above.

EXHIBIT A
MAXIMUM CAPACITY AND CO-TENANCY PERCENTAGE INTEREST Until the initial synchronization of a subsequent Project, the Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest of Roadrunner PV shall be 100%. Once each subsequent Project has been synchronized with the grid pursuant to the terms of the LGIA, the Co-Tenant that owns and operates such subsequent Project will obtain a Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest as set forth below. Project Maximum PV Capacity Maximum BESS Capacity Co-Tenancy Percentage Interest Roadrunner PV 235 MW 0 MW 50% Roadrunner BESS 0 MW 235 MW 50% TOTAL 235 MW 235 MW
In accordance with the LGIA but subject to Section 2.3, each Co-Tenant will install, own, operate and maintain a control limiting device or otherwise configure its Projects control systems to ensure that the Net Output of such Project does not exceed the Maximum PV Capacity or Maximum BESS Capacity, as applicable, set forth above, at any time. Exhibit A
record_data.filing_title: LGIA Co-Tenancy Agreement among Roadrunner Solar, Battery and BESS SF
